com.spazedog.lib.rootfw4

Class ShellStreamer

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.spazedog.lib.rootfw4.ShellStreamer

  • public class ShellStreamer
extends Object
    This class replaces the old ShellStream.

    This works as an extended version of Java's Process class. It will establish a shell connection that, unlike Process, can handle multiple streams without the need to connect/disconnect each time.

    It also introduces simple listener interfaces that makes it much easier to execute commands, collect data and handle the connections.

    This class provides a constant I/O stream to the shell. If you want to run single commands and collect the output for each, you should instead look at the Shell class.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static interface  ShellStreamer.ConnectionListener
      Listener interface that will provide notice about this streams connection state.
      static interface  ShellStreamer.StreamListener
      Listener interface that will provide details and data from streams

      This interface can be added both locally or globally.

      • connect

        public boolean connect(boolean asRoot)
        Establish a connection to a shell and start the stream queue
        Parameters:
        asRoot - Whether to use a root shell or a normal user shell
        Returns:
        TRUE if the shell was successfully established

      • disconnect

        public void disconnect()
        Destroy the shell connection and stop the stream queue.

        Unless you are running a daemon or similar that occupies the stream, consider using a more clean writeLine(String) by parsing exit 0

        A clean exit will also ensure that current streams get's to finish before the shell is terminated.

      • isConnected

        public boolean isConnected()
        Check if a connection to the shell has been established
        Returns:
        TRUE if the connection is established

      • isBusy

        public boolean isBusy()
        Check if the queue is in the process of running shell streams, in which case the shell is currently busy.
        Returns:
        TRUE if the queue is processing streams

      • startStream

        public boolean startStream(ShellStreamer.StreamListener listener)
        Add a new Stream Request to the queue. It is important to note that this will send a stream request to a stream queue handler asynchronized. This means that the stream cannot be ensured to have been started when this method returns. Alsways use the ShellStreamer.StreamListener to handle the actual stream work.

        A stream is not equel to a shell connection. You must in any case first establish a connection using connect(boolean). A stream will just start a new listener on stdout and allow writing to be made on stdin. Each new line from stdout will be sent to the ShellStreamer.StreamListener that was parsed to this specific stream.

        A stream will continue to be active until a call is made to stopStream(). Stopping a stream will not disconnect from the shell. It will just stop monitoring stdout for this ShellStreamer.StreamListener and allow others in the queue to start theirs. Note however that a stream is stopped by writing a specific pattern to the shell. This means that if the shell currently has a process running in it (daemon or similar), the stopStream() call will not work as stdout will be busy and will not receive the pattern unless/until the process stops. It is up to the user of the stream to ensure that the stream can be stopped. For example if you use cat to add content to a file, you can use "cat << 'EOF' > file" to do so and end it using "EOF" at the end, before calling stopStream(). If the ShellStreamer is not meant to be reused for other work, you can always just call disconnect() to destroy the connection.
        Parameters:
        listener - A ShellStreamer.StreamListener that should receive status and content of the stream
        Returns:
        TRUE if the request was sent to the queue

      • stopStream

        public boolean stopStream()
        Send a stop request to the current running stream.

        If you need/want to target a specific stream, call this method from inside a ShellStreamer.StreamListener belonging to that stream. Otherwise you will just target a random stream, or none if one is still in the process of being started.

      • repeatStream

        public boolean repeatStream()
        Once a stream is finished and have called ShellStreamer.StreamListener.onStreamStop(ShellStreamer, int), if this has been called in the mean time, the stream will return to the beginning and be processed once more.

        Be careful not to start an un-ending loop as this will also block other streams in the queue from being processed.

        If you need/want to target a specific stream, call this method from inside a ShellStreamer.StreamListener belonging to that stream. Otherwise you will just target a random stream, or none if one is still in the process of being started.
        Returns:
        TRUE if there is a stream to target

      • writeLine

        public boolean writeLine(String line)
        This is a simple help method for writing lines to the stream. The difference being that this method will append a line break to each parsed line.
        Parameters:
        out - Line to be written to the stream
        Returns:
        TRUE if there is a stream to target
        See Also:
        #write(byte[])}

      • write

        public boolean write(byte[] out)
        Write output to the stream

        Note that this method does not append line breaks

        If you need/want to target a specific stream, call this method from inside a ShellStreamer.StreamListener belonging to that stream. Otherwise you will just target a random stream, or none if one is still in the process of being started.
        Parameters:
        out - Bytes to be written to the stream
        Returns:
        TRUE if there is a stream to target
